parts.title: Archaeological Dig Project
parts.instruction: Questions 11-16: Choose correct letter A, B or C. Questions 17-20: Label the map.
parts.context: Information about community archaeological project at Bidcaster

questions.text: Who was responsible for starting the community project?
How was the gold coin found?

options.A: Heavy rain had removed some of the soil.
options.B: The ground was dug up by wild rabbits.
options.C: A person with a metal detector searched the area.

questions.text: What led the archaeologists to believe there was an ancient village on this site?

options.A: the lucky discovery of old records
options.B: the bases of several structures visible in the grass
options.C: the unusual stones found near the castle

questions.text: What are the team still hoping to find?
What was found on the other side of the river to the castle?

options.A: the remains of a large palace

questions.text: What do the team plan to do after work ends this summer?

options.A: prepare a display for a museum
options.B: take part in a television programme

questions.text: Label the map below. Drag the correct letter, A-G, next to Questions 17-20.

parts.title: Theatre Programmes Research
parts.instruction: Questions 21-26: Choose correct letter A, B or C. Questions 27-30: Choose FOUR answers from box A-F.
parts.context: Finn and Maya discussing their research project on theatre programmes

questions.text: Finn was pleased to discover that their topic

options.A: was not familiar to their module leader.
options.B: had not been chosen by other students.
options.C: did not prove to be difficult to research.

questions.text: Maya says a mistaken belief about theatre programmes is that

options.A: theatres pay companies to produce them.
options.C: they contain far more adverts than previously.

questions.text: Finn was surprised that, in early British theatre, programmes

options.A: were difficult for audiences to obtain.
options.B: were given out free of charge.
options.C: were seen as a kind of contract.

questions.text: Maya feels their project should include an explanation of why companies of actors

options.C: had to tour with their plays.

questions.text: Finn and Maya both think that, compared to nineteenth-century programmes, those from the eighteenth century
Maya doesn't fully understand why, in the twentieth century,

options.A: very few theatre programmes were printed in the USA.
options.B: British theatre programmes failed to develop for so long.
options.C: theatre programmes in Britain copied fashions from the USA.

questions.text: What comment is made about the programme for each of the following shows? Choose FOUR answers from the box and write the correct letter, A-F, next to Questions 27-30.

options.B: It is historically significant for a country.
options.C: It was effective at attracting audiences.
options.D: It is included in a recent project.
options.E: It contains insights into the show.

parts.title: Inclusive Design
parts.instruction: Complete the notes below. Write ONE WORD ONLY for each answer.
parts.context: Lecture about inclusive design principles and examples

questions.text: Designing products that can be accessed by a diverse range of people without the need for any ___
Not the same as universal design: that is design for everyone, including catering for people with ___ problems.
___ which are adjustable, avoiding back or neck problems
___ in public toilets which are easier to use
designers avoid using ___ in interfaces
people can make commands using a mouse, keyboard or their ___
Seatbelts are especially problematic for ___ women.
PPE jackets are often unsuitable because of the size of women's ___
PPE for female ___ officers dealing with emergencies is the worst.
The ___ in offices is often too low for women.
